description.en: The course is divided into three inter-related thematic blocks: Meaning, Intention, and Communication (the role played by mental states in linguistic communication); Mind-Reading (how are we able to know the minds of others); the Materially and Socially Extended Mind (to what extent, and in what way, does the world constitute the mind around it).
description.et: Kursus on jaotatud kolmeks omavahel seotud teemablokiks: Tähendus, kavatsus ja suhtlus (vaimuseisundite roll keelelises suhtluses); Meelte lugemine (kuidas me suudame teiste mõtteid tunda); Materiaalselt ja sotsiaalselt laiendatud meel (millises ulatuses ja kuidas on meel ümbritseva maailma poolt kujundatud).

objectives.en: This course provides an intensive introduction to topics in the Philosophy of Mind and Philosophy of Language, and develops students' argumentative writing abilities, and their capacity to do philosophy socially, through peer-review exercises and formative feedback from the lecturers.
objectives.et: Ainekursus pakub süvendatud sissejuhatuse vaimufilosoofia ja keelefilosoofia teemadesse, arendades samal ajal kaasõppijate hinnangute ja õppejõudude kujundava tagasiside kaudu üliõpilaste oskust kirjutada arutlevat teksti ja ning filosoofia tegemise sotsiaalseid oskusi.

learning_outcomes.en: A student who completes this course:

* is able to write clear, argumentative text on the three topics of philosophy of mind and language, which the course addresses. The text sets up the question to be addressed, and provides a compelling argument for an answer to this question, acknowledging any weaknesses;
learning_outcomes.et: * oskab kirjutada selget arutlevat teksti kolmel vaimu- ja keelefilosoofia teemal, mida see kursus käsitleb. Tekst püstitab käsiteldava küsimuse ja esitab veenva argumendi sellele küsimusele antud vastuse poolt, tunnistades kõiki selle nõrkusi;

learning_outcomes.en: * can engage productively in seminar discussions aimed at clarifying, critiquing, improving a philosophical thesis and arguments in its favour;
learning_outcomes.et: * suudab tulemuslikult osaleda seminari aruteludes, mille eesmärk on selgitada, kritiseerida ning täiustada mõnda filosoofilist teesi ja seda toetavaid argumente;

learning_outcomes.en: * has developed epistemic attitudes important to productive philosophical discussions: where participants are not afraid to make and acknowledge mistakes, show an interest in the reasons for and against a view;
learning_outcomes.et: * on arendanud episteemilisi hoiakuid, mis on olulised tulemuslike filosoofiliste arutelude jaoks, milles osalejad ei karda teha ega tunnistada vigu ning väljendavad huvi konkreetse vaate poolt ja vastu esitatud põhjenduste suhtes;

learning_outcomes.en: * is able to reconstruct debates in the three topics in philosophy of mind and language, which this course addresses, and to foresee and work out significant implications of theories and debates taught on these topics.
learning_outcomes.et: * suudab rekonstrueerida arutelusid kolmel vaimu- ja keelefilosoofia teemal, mida see kursus käsitleb, ning suudab ette näha ja välja töötada nende teemadega seotud teooriate ja debattide olulisi tagajärgi.

description.et:
3 essays worth an increasing proportion of the final grade (10% + 25% + 40% = 80% of final grade). Each essay is workshopped, through peer-review, in two stages in class: initially students orally pitch their arguments to a small group of peers to check that their argument is understandable and prima facie compelling, and then for a subsequent session they write a short 2-pager statement of their argument to be reviewed by a peer in class. They then write a full version of the argument, which is graded by block lecturer. Essays will be graded against the following criteria: 
10% - Paper structure and formatting are consistent, and formal requirements are satisfied.
15% - Key concepts are well-defined and used correctly within the paper.
25% - Course literature is addressed, reconstruction of the argument is adequate.
30% - Original argument is provided, it is based on clearly stated premises (and/or assumptions), premises support the conclusion.
10% - Signposting (explain what you do in each paragraph, help your reader to navigate through the paper).
10% - Overall impression (the paper is a holistic work, parts are well connected).

Student peer-review of seminar participation: seminars are settings in which philosophy is done socially--as a team, working together to better understand, critique, and build upon the ideas and arguments under discussion. A student's ability to be a good team player in a seminar context will be assessed through anonymous peer review delivered on the Teammates app (https://teammatesv4.appspot.com/web/front/home). Students will be trained, at the start of the course and after the first block of the course, in how to give feedback professionally and constructively. This feedback is given initially qualitatively after the first third of the course, and then quantitatively at the end of the course. The quantitative feedback contributes toward the student's final grade (10%).

Self-reflection: students will fill out self-reflection diaries. The entries to these diaries have two elements--for student written-work and for student seminar participation. Students will log how they responded to feedback from peers in each case, and in how they plan to change their writing/participation as the course continues. Students must provide examples in their self-reflections of both what provoked their reflection and clear examples of how this changed their subsequent writing/participation (undifferentiated--all or nothing. 10%).

grade_evaluation.et:
1. Essays = 80% of final grade. 
2. Peer review of seminar participation = 10% of final grade. 
3. Self-assessment = 10% of final grade. 

A = 90-100%
B = 80-89%
C = 70-79%
D = 60-69%
E = 50-59%
F = less than 50%

debt_elimination.et:
Retakes will not be permitted.
Late assignments may be permitted if a good reason is given, in advance, for needing to hand the assignment in late. This must be negotiated with the lecturers.

resources.recommended_materials:
A full set of reading materials will be provided on Moodle. But to get a taste of what this course includes see: 

Block 1: Meaning, Intention, and Communication 

'Logic and Conversation' in Grice, P. (1991). Studies in the Way of Words. Harvard University Press. 
Huang, M. A plea for radical contextualism. Synthese 194, 963-988 (2017). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11229-015-0982-z 
Fairweather, A., Montemayor, C., Fairweather, A., & Montemayor, C. (Eds.). (2023). Linguistic Luck: Safeguards and threats to linguistic communication. Oxford University Press. 

Block 2: Mindreading 

Maibom, H. (2009). In defence of (model) theory theory. Journal of Consciousness Studies, 16(6-7), 360-378.
Lavelle, J.S. (2021). The impact of culture on mindreading. Synthese, 198(7), pp.6351-6374.
Westra, E. and Nagel, J. (2021). Mindreading in conversation. Cognition, 210: 104618. 

Block 3: The Extended and Embodied mind 

Clark, Andy & Chalmers, David J. (1998). The extended mind. Analysis 58 (1):7-19.
Gallagher, Shaun & Zahavi, Dan (2020). The Embodied, Embedded and Extended Mind. In The Phenomenological Mind: An Introduction to Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science. 3rd ed. Routledge, 145-175
De Jaegher, H., Di Paolo, E., and Gallagher, S. (2010). Can social interaction constitute social cognition? Trends in Cognitive Sciences 14, 441-447. doi: 10.1016/j.tics.2010.06.009

description.et:
Two meetings per week: X.1, X.2. 

Intro Seminars
 
Week 1.1: Themes and Format  
Week 1.2: Peer-feedback Preparation Session: during this course students will give feedback both on their peers' participation in seminars and on their peers' written work. This session begins preparing students to give such feedback in a professional and constructive manner.

Block 1: Meaning, Intention, and Communication

Topical Seminars

Week 2.1: Up-playing conventions - Truth conditional Semantics and Logic
Week 2.2: Downplaying conventions - Implicature, Intention, Convention and Mindreading
Week 3.1: Downplaying conventions - Explicature, Mind-Reading and Its Implications
Week 3.2: Responses - Problems for communication
Week 4.1: Solutions to the Problems

Paper 1 Writing and Workshopping Seminars

Week 4.2: Pitching-sessions
Week 4.3: Peer-review of short drafts
Week 5.1: NO SEMINAR (time to write)
Week 5.2: Peer-review practice on fake student profiles + real qualitative peer-review of seminar participation of actual peers.

Block 2: Mindreading

Topical Seminars

Week 6.1: General introduction (Theory Theory and Simulation Theory)
Week 6.2: Alternatives to mind-reading in social cognition
Week 7.1: Mind-reading and the first person
Week 7.2: Mind-reading and culture
Week 8.1: What mind-reading abilities are necessary for linguistic communication

Paper 2 Writing and Workshopping Seminars

Week 8.2: Pitching-sessions
Week 9.1: Peer-review of short drafts
Week 9.2: NO SEMINAR (time to write)

Block 3: The Materially and Socially Extended Mind

Topical Seminars

Week 10.1: Extended mind, classic position and later developments 
Week 10.2: Application to the predictive coding approach 
Week 11.1: Embodiment
Week 11.2: Language and externalism (links to previous blocks on communication and mindreading)
Week 12.1: Cultural, enactive origins of mind

Paper 3 Writing and Workshopping Seminars

Week 12.2: Pitching-sessions
Week 13.1: Peer-review of short drafts
Week 13.2: NO SEMINAR (time to write)
Week 14.1: Anonymous Quantitative peer-review of peers' seminar participation
